summary: Build a portal website on ICP that hosts/links to an integrated suite of micro-apps/subsites (inspired by best-of-breed Web2/Web3 apps). Micro-apps should be easy to use with playful color-coded icons, support multilingual + multi-tenant orgs/users/vendors, integrate via shared APIs, include multi-wallet support, and provide owner/admin/user permissions with dashboards/metrics. Provide guidance on best-in-class pricing for offered services.
architectural_notes: Architecture is a portal hub + modular micro-apps/subsites connected via shared/internal APIs.
System should be multi-tenant (organizations), multi-user, and support multi-vendor.
Include multi-wallet capabilities for Web3 flows.
Access control model: Owner/Admin/User RBAC with privacy controls.
User approved proceeding with implementing the shared interoperability/backend API layer for identity, org context, roles, and activity logging across all micro-apps (AR-20).

existing_features.title: Create a portal-style home experience that serves as a hub for multiple micro-apps/subsites, including a searchable/browsable directory of micro-apps grouped by category (at minimum: AI, Banking, CashApp-like, DAOs, LinkedIn-like, Messaging, NNS, OpenChat-like, OpenClaw-like, Reddit-like, Social Media) and include additional best-of-breed categories beyond the initial list.

Implement a consistent, fun, playful, color-coded UI system for micro-app cards and navigation, using simple layouts suitable for broad age ranges. Ensure each micro-app category has a consistent color and icon style.
Add a coherent visual theme for the portal (colors, typography, layout) and apply it consistently across all screens. Avoid using a blue/purple primary palette.

Add routing and page shells for micro-apps so that each directory item opens a dedicated micro-app page (even if functionality is minimal initially). Include at least 6 starter micro-app shells inspired by the requested domains (e.g., simple social feed, basic messaging inbox UI, DAO proposals list, lightweight forum, basic vendor marketplace listing, basic AI prompt playground UI) without claiming to replicate external products.
Implement Internet Identity login and a shared identity layer in the app so all micro-app pages can access the authenticated user principal and display signed-in state.
Implement multi-organization (multi-tenant) support with the ability to create an organization, join an organization, and select an active organization context for all micro-app interactions.
Implement role-based access control with at least three roles: Owner, Admin, User. Provide basic privacy controls by enforcing role checks on sensitive endpoints and pages (e.g., dashboards/metrics).

Provide an Admin/Owner dashboard area with basic metrics and reporting across the portal and micro-app usage (e.g., counts of orgs, users, micro-app visits/opens, and recent activity). Ensure metrics are scoped by organization where appropriate.

Add multilingual infrastructure for all user-facing text (English as the default) and demonstrate at least one additional locale toggle with partial translations for core navigation and directory screens.

Add a vendors model to support “multi-vendor” scenarios: allow an organization to create and manage vendor profiles and associate them to relevant micro-app experiences (e.g., marketplace listing shell).
Add a “Pricing & Plans” page that provides guidance content for best-in-class pricing across micro-app categories, presented as editable content stored on the backend (so Admin/Owner can update).

Add generated static image assets (playful category icons + a simple portal hero graphic) and render them in the portal UI (directory cards, category headers, and landing hero). Store generated images under frontend/public/assets/generated and reference them directly from the frontend.
Fix role lookup in the frontend so that role checks use the caller principal (not the user profile object) and ensure role retrieval is consistent and reusable for all micro-apps.

Implement a frontend shared interoperability layer (a dedicated hook/module) that centralizes access to the interoperability context (profile, active organization, role) and provides a single, consistent way for micro-app pages to log activity with the correct org context.

Refactor existing micro-app shell pages that currently manually combine user profile fetching + activity logging so they use the shared interoperability layer for determining org context and logging app open events.

Add a compact test suite outline document for the shared interoperability layer that enumerates backend canister API tests for getInteropContext, getUserRole, and logActivity, including isolation tests, contract/shape assertions, multi-tenant boundary tests, workflow-chain tests, and failure-condition tests.

Include in the test suite outline a minimal, repeatable manual test execution plan using multiple identities (e.g., separate local identities for owner/admin/user) to exercise the interoperability APIs end-to-end, with concrete steps and expected outcomes.

Add comprehensive documentation explaining the access model for all micro-apps, covering: (1) how Internet Identity authentication works for the portal, (2) how the shared interoperability layer provides consistent access to user profile, active organization context, and role across all micro-apps, (3) how role-based access control (Owner/Admin/User) determines what features and pages each user can access, (4) how multi-tenant organization boundaries ensure data isolation between organizations, and (5) a high-level overview of the interop APIs (getInteropContext, getUserRole, logActivity) that micro-apps use for authentication and authorization. Place this documentation in frontend/docs/access-model-overview.md.

Create Phase 1 of the test suite setup: add a new directory frontend/src/__tests__ with a README.md that explains the test structure and provides setup instructions for running tests locally. Include in the README: (1) prerequisites (Node.js, dfx, local replica), (2) commands to install test dependencies (e.g., Vitest, Testing Library), (3) instructions to start the local replica and deploy the backend canister for testing, (4) how to run the test suite, and (5) a brief overview of the test categories (isolation, contract, multi-tenant, workflow, failure).

Create Phase 2 of the test suite setup: implement starter test files for the shared interoperability layer based on the test suite outline (frontend/docs/shared-interop-test-suite-outline.md). Create at least three test files: (1) frontend/src/__tests__/interop-isolation.test.ts covering isolation tests for getInteropContext, getUserRole, and logActivity with unauthenticated/authenticated states, (2) frontend/src/__tests__/interop-contract.test.ts covering contract/shape assertions for the three interop APIs to validate returned data structures, and (3) frontend/src/__tests__/interop-multitenant.test.ts covering multi-tenant boundary tests to ensure organization data isolation. Each test file should include at least 2-3 concrete test cases with describe/it blocks, mock actor setup, and assertions aligned with the test suite outline. Use Vitest as the test framework.

Add a comprehensive step-by-step guide to frontend/src/__tests__/README.md explaining how to run the test suite locally, including: (1) starting the local dfx replica with 'dfx start --clean --background', (2) deploying the backend canister with 'dfx deploy backend', (3) installing test dependencies with 'npm install --save-dev vitest @vitest/ui @testing-library/react @testing-library/jest-dom happy-dom', (4) running tests with 'npm test' or 'npx vitest', (5) running tests in UI mode with 'npx vitest --ui', and (6) troubleshooting common issues like canister connection errors or missing environment variables.

Add npm scripts to package.json for running tests: (1) 'test' script that runs 'vitest run' for single execution, (2) 'test:watch' script that runs 'vitest' for watch mode, (3) 'test:ui' script that runs 'vitest --ui' for interactive UI mode, and (4) 'test:coverage' script that runs 'vitest run --coverage' if coverage tooling is configured.

Update frontend/src/__tests__/README.md to include a 'Quick Start' section at the top with a condensed command sequence for experienced developers: start replica, deploy backend, install deps, run tests. Place this above the detailed step-by-step instructions.

Implement concrete test cases in frontend/src/__tests__/interop-isolation.test.ts with at least 3 tests: (1) test that getInteropContext returns null when called without authentication, (2) test that getUserRole returns null for unauthenticated calls, and (3) test that logActivity requires authentication and returns an error or throws when called unauthenticated. Use vitest describe/it blocks with mock actor setup and assertions.

Implement concrete test cases in frontend/src/__tests__/interop-contract.test.ts with at least 3 tests: (1) test that getInteropContext returns an object with expected shape (principal, profile, activeOrg, role fields), (2) test that getUserRole returns a valid UserRole enum value ('owner', 'admin', or 'user') or null, and (3) test that logActivity accepts the expected parameters (microAppId, actionType, metadata) and returns a success indicator. Use vitest describe/it blocks with mock actor setup and shape validation assertions.

Implement concrete test cases in frontend/src/__tests__/interop-multitenant.test.ts with at least 3 tests: (1) test that getInteropContext only returns data for organizations the user belongs to, (2) test that getUserRole returns null when querying a role for an organization the user is not a member of, and (3) test that logActivity is scoped to the user's active organization and does not leak data across organization boundaries. Use vitest describe/it blocks with mock actor setup simulating multiple organizations and assertions validating data isolation.

Implement the test setup utilities in frontend/src/__tests__/setup.ts including: (1) a createMockActor utility function that returns a mock backend actor with stub implementations of getInteropContext, getUserRole, and logActivity, (2) test fixtures for UserProfile, InteropContext, and Organization objects with realistic sample data, (3) helper functions to generate mock principals for testing, and (4) a beforeEach hook that resets all mocks and clears state between tests.

Research and document available replica micro-apps from the CaffeineAI system that can be cloned and adapted. Create a markdown document at frontend/docs/caffeineai-replica-apps.md listing each available replica app with its name, description, primary features, current implementation status, and assessment of adaptation complexity for this portal.

Clone the most suitable CaffeineAI replica micro-app for the Social Media category and adapt it to work within the portal's multi-tenant architecture. Integrate it with the shared interoperability layer (useInteropContext hook) for authentication, organization context, and activity logging. Replace the existing SocialFeedShell.tsx with the adapted replica app implementation while maintaining the portal's coral/orange visual theme and role-based access controls.

Clone the most suitable CaffeineAI replica micro-app for the Messaging category and adapt it to work within the portal's multi-tenant architecture. Integrate it with the shared interoperability layer for authentication, organization context, and activity logging. Replace the existing MessagingInboxShell.tsx with the adapted replica app implementation while maintaining the portal's visual theme and ensuring messages are scoped to the user's active organization.

Clone the most suitable CaffeineAI replica micro-app for the Forum/Reddit-like category and adapt it to work within the portal's multi-tenant architecture. Integrate it with the shared interoperability layer for authentication, organization context, and activity logging. Replace the existing ForumShell.tsx with the adapted replica app implementation while maintaining the portal's visual theme and ensuring forum topics/threads are scoped to the user's active organization.

Update the adapted replica micro-app frontend components to connect to the new backend data models using React Query hooks. Create custom hooks (useSocialPosts, useConversations, useForumTopics) that fetch and mutate data from the backend, handle loading and error states, and automatically invalidate queries when data changes. Ensure hooks respect the active organization context from useInteropContext.

Add real-time update capabilities to the adapted replica micro-apps by implementing polling or periodic query refetching for social posts, messages, and forum topics. Configure React Query to refetch data at appropriate intervals (e.g., every 30 seconds for messaging, every 60 seconds for social feed and forum) so users see new content without manual refresh.

Update the micro-apps catalog in frontend/src/catalog/microAppsCatalog.ts to reflect the enhanced functionality of the three adapted replica apps (social feed, messaging, forum). Update their descriptions to indicate they now support real user-generated content, multi-tenant data isolation, and real-time updates. Ensure the catalog still references the correct route slugs and category assignments.
